posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
SF's gameplay is fairly underrated. People see lack of dual analog controls and shoulder buttons being used for strafing and immediately feel some kind of dissonance but I can't state enough how much I enjoy the gameplay and how smooth everything in those 3 games feel.

Framerate is steady - not great but steady. Going into manual mode puts you in the headshot plane and all you need to do is sweep horizontally with the dpad, and the sensitivity is great and pulling off spectacular shots is very easy. If the enemy is crouching, then all you need to do is crouch yourself and that fixes the vertical side of aiming.

I also really love how every single weapon in the game is a guaranteed one-hit kill if you do a headshot. And that even shotguns are lethal and accurate at long range.
Auto-aim also has suprising amount of depth - your body direction affects the accuracy so your accuracy is the best when you are walking head-on towards the enemy and worse when you are strafing. Just the gameplay loop is very fun and every weapon sees equal amount of use .

SF1 has some annoying respawning issues but generally speaking all 3 games are top tier action games with some very memorable level design. I wish everyone gave these games a chance.

>>9483251
I've spent probably 30 hours in the last three months playing this game after having not really messed with it since 2015. And I realized...
I truly love this game. The story and pacing is the perfect kind of jank that can fuel hours of silly stupid headcanons. I have nothing but fun with the gunplay and the ridiculousness of a military or alien force being mowed down by a four foot edgie hedgie with a twenty-foot long gatling gun screams COOL, RIDICULOUS, and BADASS all at the same time. Shooting down giant flying craft by just endlessly spamming dakka while rushing to find more ammo fires off the synapses in my brain that give me joy. And it's so buttery slick to control, but doesn't suffer the same SA1 problem where you can set yourself back 20-30 seconds five times over because the speed overwhelms the controls, it's just death or a light punishment for being a retard. And the meters letting you spam extra dakka, or just randomly delete entire sections of the level with some well placed jumps? Wonderful
And oh the set pieces! It's so awesome to revisit the corridors of the ARK and even see entirely new sections from the far past, I love the grim-derp take on the Sonic highway gimmick, the gaudy colors of the light rail sections. Do you want some moderately-difficult platforming? We got that. You want some piss-easy platforming? We got that. You want no platforming and just want to blow up bombs or mow down enemies? We got that also! And above all, it's not trying to be a Sonic game, it commits to being it's own thing.

I don't care if everyone else hates it for a thousand reasons. This game brings me childlike joy even in my late twenties. The *only* thing I don't like is the opening level, the first 30 seconds are fantastic for setpiecing but you spend the rest of it going down a dull single street for a silly enemy hunt, could have at least split the path at least once like what Air Fleet did.

This is a bit misleading. The Dreamcast's real discs were a custom format with more capacity than a CD, so many (most?) games are too big to fit on a CD, and to burn them you have to use shitty scene releases that compress or remove content. You can get around this by using an ODE (optical drive emulator), but it's more expensive and complicated than just burning discs.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Development_of_Duke_Nukem_Forever

>The video game Duke Nukem Forever spent more than 14 years in development, from 1996 to 2011. It is a first-person shooter for Windows, PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360,[1] developed by 3D Realms, Triptych Games, Gearbox Software and Piranha Games. It is the sequel to the 1996 game Duke Nukem 3D, as part of the long-running Duke Nukem video game series. Intended to be groundbreaking, it became an infamous example of vaporware due to its severely protracted development schedule; it had been in development under 3D Realms since 1996. Director George Broussard, one of the creators of the original Duke Nukem game, announced the development in 1997, and promotional information for the game was released from 1997 until its release in 2011.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9485398
Your post is even more misleading. Most games can be shrunk to fit on a "standard" capacity CD without removing anything but unused space. Most of what can't will fit on a larger capacity CD, which are easily obtainable by any adult with an IQ>70. There are not so shitty scene releases that compress content using more efficnet systems than the original and have negligible loss in quality. Some discs contain content that's not part of the game, not used by the game, and can be removed/moved to another disc without affecting the game in any way. In reality there are only a handfull of games where this is a real problem.
Using an ODE should be less complicated than burning discs, and not much more expensive if at all. Anyone who didn't buy GDEMUs for all their DCs when they were <$40 is a zoomer bandwagoner and thus irrelevent.

>>9485479
It's late 1999 and the other consoles out at the time are the PS1, N64, and Saturn. Games on all of these systems either ran like crap and/or looked like crap. If you had a Dreamcast from this period to when it got canned in early 2001 you had a system that had the best looking, most action packed games at the time on top of running silky smooth. Oh, and great 4 player games that didn't require a multitap or ran at 5 frames a second. It feels sorta underwhelming today and nothing special, like the original SMB or Half Life, but put your head in the mindset of gamers at the time and you'll see that there was literally nothing like it and understand why it was so appreciated.

It's full of gimmicks from visuals (rain, snow), platforming gimmicks (barrels, ropes) and is mechanically ultra simplistic. Far simpler than even the simplified master system sonic games. It's not meant to be a challenging game or deep game, and it is neither of these. They succeed in making the perfectly mediocre platformer to show off their pre-rendered graphics.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9464565
Prototyping ASICs. That's basically the reason they were invented.
Aviation and automation. It's cheaper in the long run to run the onboard software on an FPGA simulated ASIC than an actual ASIC because when some new bullshit law comes in that demands your component respond 0.0001% faster you can just update the hardware with new HDL at a routine service, rather than expensive downtime at a factory where somebody has to literally take it apart and solder a new chip on, and you don't have an expensive new ASIC run to produce.
Military. Same deal. Any hardware flaws can be fixed in the field, you don't have to say "sorry Vlad, can we postpone the war, we're upgrading our nukes to Ryzen."

>>9467459
>I'm still not sure what this thing is
You're familiar with the term FPGA, in a loose fashion, yeah? MiSTer is a project that is taking advantage of a cheap FPGA that people can buy, called the DE-10 Nano. The DE-10 Nano is cheap because it is made for college students, and is subsidized by Intel. The DE-10 Nano has an FGPA on board, as well as an ARM chip. It has various connectors on the board for expandability. MiSTer has a bunch of FPGA cores (much like the cores you would see on one of the Analog systems) for consoles, handhelds, arcade boards and computers. Developers are constantly adding more cores and improving on existing cores. A hobbiest community has popped up around this project, which has led to a lot of hardware addons that can be installed onto the DE-10 Nano, such as extra RAM, a digital or analog I/O board, USB hub (these things make up the most common MiSTer setup that you have likely seen, which is a sandwich of three boards with the DE-10 Nano in the middle)... etc. There are people who have made specialized expansion boards like the MiSTercade, which allows it to be used in a typical JAMMA arcade cabinet. At a base level, you really just need the DE-10 Nano, and preferably a RAM stick, the rest is optional.

MiSTer can be appealing to enthusiasts because it offers better accuracy/latency compared to software emulation. It's also very easy to set up and use in a variety of scenarios, without having to invest in a bunch of extra shit like flash carts, upscalers, custom cables... etc. It is an all-in-one solution for many of the systems that a retro gamer would be interested in. By its nature, it is also very customizable.

I still think that software emulation is a good option, especially on a budget since you can probably do it on hardware that you already own, however I do like my MiSTer quite a bit and I find that I am playing more /vr/ games than ever since getting it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's the perfect middle ground. You've got original hardware accurate latency, perfect audio timing, ease of use with a CRT and compatibility with a number of peripherals, tied with loading roms, save states for some cores, using any controller you want, and emulation perks like CPU overclocking for SNES.

If you're into collecting and playing carts, then go real hardware. But if you were just going to buy flash carts for all of your systems, I don't see any reason not to just go the mister route. You're getting the same console quality experience. And you don't have to worry about shit like HDMI mods for your hardware, or upscalers like the retrotink if you want to hook it up to a modern TV, it has all that built in. You don't have to worry about RGB modding hardware to get the most clarity, it's all just built in.

I think it's a really nifty option and I have no clue why /vr/ shits themselves over it

Everdrives are great if you want to play on dedicated consoles. Excellent if you already have real hardware and don't mind buying a unique everdrive for each console.

There is no best way, only options in which you weigh out the benefits for yourself.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9464069
Runahead latency isn't accurate. FPGA is latency accurate, in that a good core can reasonably achieve identical latency to original hardware.

Additionally the overhead to achieve accurate latency is much easier. Software emulators generally try for timing accuracy or cycle accuracy with a lot of optimization and tricks required to do so. With FPGA once you've defined the logic it mostly just works how you'd expect.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9464110
With FPGA the actual video circuit of the recreated system directly drives the raster of the CRT, just like the original hardware could. You will always have a framebuffer on PC, always some abstraction away from native interf
aces.

>>9471772
>I'm playing MRA2 as well. Do you have any tip for a first-timer?
Nothing really specific to this games campaign as I haven't really bothered with finding many secrets or anything, but some basic tips on raising monsters, you may already know all this but....

Always make sure you relieve monsters "stress" and "fatigue", always let it rest obviously but also use items like oil or mintcandy to remove fatigue after training and battles. Battling itself actually helps remove monsters stress. As you accumulate larger amounts of cash, it's definitely good to prioritize buying all the more expensive stress relieving, fatigue relieving, and sleep helping items you'll see in the shop like the cups and gems, as can afford them of course, don't skip out on them, they'll make it easier for new monsters. Also don't let your monster get fat or malnourished, fat monsters get fatigued more and underweight monsters get stressed more.

Also take it easy on baby monsters, just do the most basic training until its more mature aka when Holly tells gives you that cue that it's an "important time" or whatever she says, that's when you start the coach routines

Always focus on like 3, maybe 4 main stats to train your monster in. Having a balanced monster doesn't really work because there's only so much time you can put into training during its lifespan, you want your monster to excel hard in specific areas, not be average in many areas, so take that into consideration when deciding what monster you wanna raise and how you want it to grow/what moves you want it to learn

When you're stronger and start doing sparring with the intention of learning new moves specifically, it's not really worth it unless you're gonna learn a new move, so don't bother wasting the money and time unless it says there's a chance your monster will learn a new move, and honestly I say theres no shame in saving before and restarting until you learn the move

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Just finished it after having skipped it back in the day for whatever reason.

Solid sequel. Feels a bit by like I'm just going through the motions from Prime 1 but its a damn solid game considering Retro shat it out in barely what, a year and a half? Dark World gives it its own identity, and the level design overall is some of the best in the series with criss-crossing paths and multi-layered levels galore. Specifically the underwater section in Torvus is great with its central room and the corridors running around it which you figure out by constantly jumping back and forth in the world.

Difficulty is massively overrated, its not significantly harder than MP1. I was dreading the boost guardian after hearing so much about him yet beat him on my second try.

I'm not too big a fan of the Ing as the main enemy, they come off as Zergling ripoffs but with DARKNESS and feel very impersonal. In fact, the whole Luminoth conflict just makes me feel like an errand boy with how video gamey it is. (Oh glorious Samus, go to the three temples and get the macguffin for we are fucking useless)

Then the Space pirates and Dark Samus are just kind of there for some reason.

If you like Prime 1, its essentially more Prime for you to sink your teeth into. Defo worth a go if you haven't played it.

In the dark Ing Hive level where the spinning reactor room normally is in Sanctuary Fortress I didn't notice the glass that divides you from the reactor which normally was there in the light version was gone in the dark version and spent hours looking for a way into the dark reactor room.

Boost guardian is hated because if you don't do the thing, then it's logically impossible to beat him on hard mode. He'll just do more damage than you.

The thing is to, you know, hit him when he's just a puddle on the floor. You can hit enemies when they're goop on the walls or floor, but a lot of players don't do this because it requires manual aiming in a GCN Metroid game. Many players assume you're only allowed to hit him when he's not a puddle, because that's the only time the game will lock onto him.

Because of this thread, I decided to give MP2 a shot again. Haven't played it since 05.

I remember why I didn't like it, but that's not as strong as it was before. The map in the game is next to useless and it's best to pretend there's no markers on it, since they're just as likely to convince you to go the wrong way as to tell you what is going on (you know, the purpose of a map). I appreciate the game's hard mode, MP1's biggest problem is how easy it is. I don't mind the ammo to a degree, but at the same time I still don't really understand why it's there. I think I agree with teenage me when I repeat the opinion that they could have improved on MP1 when overall they weighed it down, but I'm not mad about it like back then. I feel like the game should have been more about making the combat faster paced than 1 and try to play into the strength of the first two games' first person platformer formula. Instead we get MP1 with a better hard mode (which is good) and shit level design because of the light/dark world.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9457750
It's the rotation rules ("Super Rotation System" is what it stands for) that The Tetris Company mandates, among other things that publishers who license Tetris must abide by to be given an official stamp of approval (referred to in whole as the "Tetris Guideline").

They're very nitpicky about this, even going so far as to decommission older Tetris games (like Game Boy Tetris) for retroactively not abiding by their ruleset.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Honestly given how stringent they are I'm surprised they still get involved with the Classic Tetris World Championships since NES Tetris definitely doesn't adhere to any modern interpretation of the game.

>>9483134
much appreciated, although after slaving away at these games for three years i'd consider myself mildly competent at best lol. it's been quite a while since i frequented ta.p
it's been long enough that i'm already starting to forget the things that helped me succeed so i'll just regurgitate the advice i usually give to people in your position:
>read tgm.tips, the tetris wiki, and old tetrisconcept threads like they're your personal bible (disc*rd is occasionally helpful if you're willing to use the fucking thing and can handle it responsibly)
>watch tgm superplays on youtube at 0.5x speed and analyze what each player does while trying to predict their next move - if they do something different, ask yourself why they made that decision and if it was the better play in hindsight. you can't think piece-by-piece, you have to consider how your stack is going to affect you in the long run
>grind 20g, do it in a clone like texmaster or with the 20g cheat. it sounds terrifying, but a common suggestion i saw was to grind death in tap until you can get used to the lower level speeds and i actually recommend that, if you can hit death 300 you can probably get tgm1 gm. ars seems scary until you realize it's restrictive enough there are only a few places you can put down a piece at any given time, which makes it easier to stack - 20g restricts your options further, it's mostly a matter of learning *how* to put the pieces where you want
>get used to abusing irs as much as you can
>i'm awful at not choking, but my advice: misdropping once is not the end of the world, look for downstacking opportunities and take them as soon as you can. 20g and death in particular will force you to git gud at this
>this isn't too relevant until you start time attacking, but avoid clearing singles since it wastes time
i can't fucking find when i did it but it took me at least 3 or 4 months to go from breaking level 500 to getting gm, keep chipping away at it and you'll get it soon enough

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Basically when games and technology started specifically aiming for a photorealistic picture, is when "retro" truly ended. To me what we call retro - both 2D and early 3D - is not about dates but rather about artistic merits of working around major technical limitations, which is what made those games so good. When every game looked absolutely different and unique because they were all hyper-stylized artistic depictions of reality seen through the prism of artistry of creative people. Not so much anymore when 90% of the entire development process goes towards making everything look how it does in real life - which is, you know, the same. When the 7th gen started we didn't just gain things like upgrades in storage space and resolution, for the first time in history we started progressively losing things, losing artistry, because there were no more major technical limitations to overcome. More and more elements started becoming token. So much so that we saw the rise of tertiary elements like online becoming more popular than the games themselves.

I wouldn't mind this definition but I also don't mind including GC/PS2/Faggotbox either. Looking back with the benefit of hindsight regarding what I hate the most about games & consoles today, I see that generation as being relatively pure. Experimental market-poking and prodding happened, but it wasn't the norm, and I fully expect to have to deal with these being called retro by my weaker brethren en masse someday.

With the Wii/PS3/Faggotbox360 they were becoming more committed to their modern, forwadd-looking hardware identity, but they were still only experimenting with the rot. It had evolved from a question of permissions to a question of facilitation. It was the Switch/PS4/FaggotboxOne generation where all three companies had fully committed to modern rot concepts. Their hardware angle was set and leaned into, their policy and strategy on the brave new werld of microtransactions, unfinished beta AAA releases, bloatgramming, and various other consumer abuses that old games lack were set and normalized.

Maybe retro can be defined by exactly in which ways companies abused consumers. Back in the day your lives were tied to a real life quarter that you popped into the machine, so the market wanted HARD games that you learned to play by dying repetitively. When the move to console came it wasn't long till this shifted. Instead of incessantly killing you (unpopular with millenials), the games were filled with meaningless content and time wasters. Companies believed that time spent playing on a home console was a sales leader driving new game purchases. Sounds right to me. Eventually it shifted again though, and everything reminds me of the itunes/googleplaystore now. I'm almost done typing. Microsoft is gay and if you pay them money you are also gay, good night /vr/

The actual retro is arcades and the age before the mass spread of personal computers and consoles. When games were programmed in universities by enthusiasts.

Afterwards it's much less distinct and there are several weirdly overlapping niches between actual consoles and various kinds of home computers. But the third large change, separating that zoo from what came next, is definitely 3D. This was the summit of ambition back then and in retrospect I don't understand how anyone who was alive and into video games back then didn't get sick of hearing "3D" all the time.

All this "six gen" and "seven gen" is completely alien even to that previous age because Mass Effect sure isn't retro in any way.
The "problem" lies with the board's name because if it actually was for retro games only it would've had activity comparable to /po/.

>Wrong. So backwards compatibility makes games not retro anymore? Ps3 plays ps1. I guess ps1 isn't retro now. Derp.
Let me rephrase it, for anons with poor reading comprehension.
Any consoles released after 1st January 2000 aren't retro. Games for these consoles released after this date would still be retro.
Final Fantasy 9 would still be a retro game since it was developed for and released for the PS1, a console that was first released in late 1994, despite the game itself being released in mid-2000.
So would Digimon World 3, despite being released in 2003.
For PC games the cut-off would be 31st December 2004, with some exceptions. Half-Life 2 can't really be considered retro, while Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines could, since it inherits so much from 2000's Deus Ex.

A new generations model, not based on years, but on hardware and gameplay:
1 - Pre-NES.
2 - NES-TG16-SMS.
3 - SNES-SMD-GB-PS1.
4 - PS1-N64-SAT.
5 - PS2-Wii era, incl. GBA and DS.
6 - PS3-360-WiiU era, incl. 3ds.
7 - Xbone-PS4 thru today.
Nintendo since Wii has dropped a generation behind the pack. I think the major problem with the previous model was basing it off of Nintendo's consoles as if they represented the pack, when really they are notable outliers. Look at them today especially, their main system is a handheld! To say the switch is the representative of modern gaming isn't entirely accurate, it more represents the previous generation's staying power.
Look at human beings. There are 4 or 5 generations living today. They are each different, but one's inception is not necessarily the other's demise. a generation lasts as long as it is able to compete for market space. 8bit did it for a whole decade on a puny B&W screen, but it stuck it out!

>>9477718
My first year in college I had some classes with people who were borderline illiterate and couldn't do remedial math but were still delusional enough to think that they could hack through and become nurses or programmers or whatever. So instead of just admitting they were in over their heads they plowed ahead, submitted their papers, took the tests, waited for their obligatory "you tried, here's a C-" and then they flunked out after one semester.

That's what the game.com reminds me of. It's easy to think that this was just a cynical attempt to separate suckers from their money but I think there was actually a kind of tragic sincerity behind it. Like, Tiger really thought they'd stepped it up. It was an actual console! With Sonic! And Resident Evil! They were rubbing shoulders with Sony and Sega like a real game company...just long enough to embarrass themselves and confirm they didn't belong before withdrawing in shame.

Like, Imagine being the guys who put together that RE2 port. It died on arrival and was always going to but...it's not nothing. The game actually has a lot of content to it. Redundant, shitty content but somebody still had to make it and they probably had to put some effort into it. I honestly want to know what became of the people who made these things. Did they know they were working on a thankless task? Did they think they were making the game.com's greatest hit? Were they cynical mercenaries or dreamers whose dreams were shattered? Why does my autistic brain think about these things?

I look at the Game.Com hardware and I just don't know what to say about it. On one side, Tiger was on the right path with many of the ideas. The handheld has enough buttons, it was the first with a touch screen and stylus pen before the DS. The system is 8-bit like the Gameboy, and is in some ways better and worse. It has a faster CPU, and can throw some pretty big (for the system) sprites on screen. It seems to be able to play back audio samples. The weird midi-music system it has seems to be horrible. Games run at 5-10FPS. Most of the games for this system look partially broken or completely broken. It is still an evolution over the tiger electronic games. Look at this game based on the movie The Lost World:

This is one of those games that would look good in screen shots, because some of the sprites and art do look good. But, it also looks bad at the same time. I feel like there was almost something there with the Game.com. But by 1998, the Game Boy Color was out on the market at the same price.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9491279
>Cheap Capcom sticks with no arcade parts
Incorrect.

The Capcom Power Stick fighter used arcade parts, for both lever and button switches.
The black PSF used Sanwa levers based on JLW, and the white version used an unlabeled LS-40.
Both versions use Tokai MM9 microswitches for the buttons. Exactly the same as Seimitsu used in their arcade buttons. Only the plunger is custom to the stick, and the plungers are 24mm in diameter just like a 24mm arcade button.

In short: you're completely wrong.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: during which generation did loss leader consoles become standard practice? I would assume this would require a generation or two under a company's belt to build up capital to afford this approach, excluding cases like Sony where they just showed up to the game with capital to spare. when did it become a rule rather than an exception?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9490274
>I would assume stupid things
Many such cases
Most businesses aren't children who need to save up their allowance to buy shit. Atari had been making arcade systems for several years before launching the 2600. Coleco had been around for decades and was a household name. Startups can get financing through banks or investors.
I don't know if Atari intended for the 2600 to be a loss leader, but that's how it turned out. The company lost money hand over fist until they had their first truly successful game, years after launch. And this wasn't some new marketing strategy invented for video games. It'd been around for ages and people quickly realized that it worked for video games just like pretty much any other product.

>>9492001
The C64 was really cheap to build because commodore had their own factories and assembly plants. They made like 450% profit per unit on its launch day and over 200% in 1984 when the price was cut down to $150. Jack Tramiel was a highly experienced, brilliant, and fierce computer businessman who understood how the industry and the computer hardware worked while Nintendo was headed by an egocentric bean counter. Nintendo and Sega wouldn't stand a chance against Commodore if they decided to seriously tap into the gaming business.

I will admit the idea wasn't fully realized tough, it has legitimate blemishes, many people of course focus on the overusing of Finale Toccata, filling the map with the mist or wolf in the reverse caverns because they should remap the level design of that part, and that some areas are optional but ultimately pointless, like there really is no reason to go to the reverse castle entrance.

My idea to fix this is to have the last transformation upgrade, the poison mist, NOT be after beating Galamoth, but instead put it in the reverse castle entrance, maybe even fixing and making the unused secret passage (for the unfinished area that was a wet fart on the saturn port), instead of having a pointless save point there, have special items there, and in the reverse castle, you get the Poison Mist there.

That to me seems to be the biggest issue with the reverse castle, mediocre distribution of lut, the actual traversing aint much of an issue, maybe not with the wolf no more due to the main terrain being less flat, but the Wing Smash definitively aids a lot, i would have an upgrade to the wing smash that makes it last longer, but then again you can actually keep repeating it with good timing, while the saturn port actually keeps it goin until you run out of magic or crash to a solid vertical wall

Hell why not having access to all the teleporters unlocked so you can really explore more easier the reverse castle.

I still take it over Aria and Dawn ''true final areas'' and HoD lazy ''dual castles'' which are mostly the same aside from a few rooms having different design layouts.

There's a fantastic PE artbook on archive.org.
https://archive.org/details/ParasiteEveNewType
It has storyboards for all the CGI sequences and, since they were made by Square's American office, all the notes are in English. I had to downsize and compress this to meet the filesize limits, but they're easily legible in the actual scans. There's some neat content that got cut in a few of them too. The alligator and dog transformations have some extra shots, there's a whole cutscene of Aya falling into the sewer that I don't remember ever actually happening in-game, and the scene with pregnant Eve in the museum is significantly longer, among other things.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Thread for introducing anon's to classic point & click adventure games.

>What qualifies as a classic point & click adventure game?
Games which are first person or isometric, which require movement or progression from using a pointer to advance, pick up objects, and/or solve puzzles. They can be 2D sprites, FMV, or 3D.

>POINT OF THIS THREAD
If you are a P&C virgin, or are somewhat new to P&C games, or simply don't care but would be interested in exploring more of them, this thread is for you. Just ask for recc's for anything in particular.

>RESOURCES
UNIVERSAL HINT SYSTEM - If you are forced cheat and look up the solutions to puzzles, do it through this website. It does not give you the answer to puzzles outright, instead opting to give you more and more detailed hints, and has virtually every single classic, as well as many new, P&C games.
https://www.uhs-hints.com/

ADVENTURE GAME DATABASE - Has nearly every single adventure game you could possibly think of, with the genre's they belong to, screenshots, availability, platforms, development info, and a summary of the game.
https://www.adventuregamedb.com

DEAD END GUIDES - Websites which blatantly state all the known dead-end states in the most well-known Sierra franchises.
https://kingsquest.fandom.com/wiki/Dead_end
https://policequest.fandom.com/wiki/Dead_End
https://spacequest.fandom.com/wiki/Dead_End

>NOTABLE DESIGNERS
Roberta Williams
Tim Schafer
Al Lowe
Ron Gilbert
The Coles (Corey Cole, Lori Ann Cole)
Steve Meretzky

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9490850
>That should be the one thing Point and Click games should have going for them in exchange for 0 action.
Where to start, where to start...
1 - No, it isn't, why would time and events matter at all if there is "zero action"? The most someone would expect from a game with zero action should be characters, then story, then plot, then animation, then world-building.

2 - Puzzle solving is action. Not all action needs to be combat based with megaman-esque "SHOOT THE THING TILL IT DIES!" or Ninja Gaiden-esque "SLASH THE THING TILL IT DIES!" gameplay, you zoomer.

3 - I have no idea what you're talking about in regards to point and click games having "Zero action". Even if you don't include puzzle solving, for some bizarre reason, there's still plentiful examples, such as the Quest for Glory games, the Conquests games, the Indiana Jones games, Even in games with no combat mechanics, you still directly and indirectly "fight" various enemies, such as in King's Quest 1 where you fight/defeat a Giant (which you defeat with a slingshot), a Dragon (which you defeat with a bucket of water), a Troll (which you defeat with a goat), and a Witch (which you push into a boiling cauldron), and there's examples like this in most point and click games.

But even still, going back to your original point, Quest For Glory 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 all have a consistent time-based events system. The Colonel's Bequest is another one, along with Conquests of the Longbow. Even Secret of Monkey Island has combat in it.

You basically get as much as you'll most likely ever get out of a Street Fighter character by literally looking at them fight, and often that isn't even necessary. You still get the SNK approach in SF characters though, like Karin in A3 or Remy in TS.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9487747
If it was just an overlay of lines, it'd be nothing.
But a proper shader is separating red, green, and blue signals for each pixel into separate phosphors, applying distortion onto the overall image, specific blending properties based on adjacent colors, etc. And all of this has to be done to every pixel on every rendered frame.
On top of the game being played in the first place, it's a lot.

>>9475092
Halo itself was a great series but its influence on the industry was pretty disastrous. Mainly it standardized dual stick + aim assist aiming for consoles which is awful because its designed to trick console players into thinking its not there, and it just aims for them. At the time it was the only solution that could have worked but now that both Sony and Nintendo have controllers that support dual stick + gyro aim, thats the far better way to aim in console shooters, debatably on par with KBM, but aim assist will never go away because console players are far too accustomed to it.

Ask any PC gamer what they think of console FPS and most of them disapprove solely because of the aim assist control scheme - something that console only casuls will never notice. And superior aim methods that are now possible will never take off because Halo caused one thing to be too well established.

>“When I joined Namco Hometek in 1996, the artists and programming team were finishing up another game, so the design team was tasked to develop a new title. We came up with 8 games – 4 original and 4 based on Namco properties. We met with the head of the studio, a Japanese gentleman, for a pitch session. After we were done, we asked him “Which idea do you like best?” He thought for a moment and said “Which one do YOU like?” We pointed to one of the original ideas. He shook his head and said: “No. Develop one of the Namco ones further.” So we went back and polished up the four designs. I remember one was based on the Namco theme park Namja Town, another was an RPG that featured all of Namco’s lead characters, the third was Splatterhouse and the last one was Pac-man Ghost Zone. We had another meeting and at the end, we asked him: “Which one do you like?” (You’d think we would have learned by now.) He replied “Which one do YOU like?” We said we really liked the Namco RPG. He said: “No. Do Pac-Man.” And that’s how Pac-Man Ghost Zone was started.
https://playstationmuseum.com/PACMANGZ.html
I dunno, that plus the rest of the restrictions makes me sympathize with the devs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9490415
The best ways to emulate PC98 in 2022 is Neko Project II Kai which is a Retroarch core.
If there is a single benefit to Retroarch is that it's ported to almost everything. If the OS of your smart TV is Android-based, then you might have some luck running PC98 games on it.
Dosbox X gave me better performance compared to Anex, but it takes a little longer to configure.
Anex was the go to PC98 emulator for a while, but it's not the case anymore since better options exist.

Explain me this people.
How comes that the 1994 Gameboy title is so much better compared to its sequels on later much more advanced consoles?
With modern Nintendo, a handheld game with solid foundation (NSMB, Mario 3D Land) usually spawned a much more complex sequels on the home consoles, yet it's not the case with 1994's Gameboy Donkey Kong.
Mario vs. Donkey Kong for the GBA has an interesting visual style, but in terms of players movement agency and the level structure it's an obvious downgrade.
The next installment is literally a Lemmings clone that barely resembles its origin.
It's especially unfortunate given that most of the games released for the original gameboy, were limited reimplementations of grander console titles.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's not as popular now as it used to be, but it's still alive. Every version has at least one private server.

Most populated servers for each version:
Dreamcast: Sylverant https://sylverant.net
Gamecube: Schthack https://schtserv.com
Xbox: Schthack https://schtserv.com
PC: Ephinea https://ephinea.pioneer2.net

Gamecube and Xbox are similar enough to crossplay, and they just got it working mere weeks ago. But Dreamcast and PC versions are too different from the others for crossplay to work.

PC is the most popular version these days, and in some ways the best one, as it's the only one with Episode 4.

If you want to play on a console, I'd recommend the Gamecube version on a Wii. Dreamcast is missing Episode 2. Getting ethernet hardware for either Dreamcast or Gamecube is expensive. Cheaper on an Xbox obviously, but that's still a little glitchy - I see Xbox players disconnecting a lot.

Wii is cheap and easy to hack (https://wii.guide), only requires a USB adapter for ethernet, which you can find for $10 on Ebay (although make sure you get the right one). Once you have that, the homebrew app Nintendont will load the game and emulate the Broadband Adapter.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9473260
Absolutely. Especially if you can get friends in on the splitscreen multiplayer. One of the things that impressed me most about PSO on GCN is that everyone can have their own characters on their own memory cards, and are completely independent. If you start a party with friends in FF Crystal Chronicles, your character is stuck in that party. In PSO though, you can play with one group of friends one day, and then take your memory card and use the same character with a completely different group of friends the next day. 4 players can play together with 4 different characters on 4 different memory cards, even though the gamecube only has 2 memory card ports.

One caveat though; the camera sucks in split screen. Don't jump straight into multiplayer with four level 1 characters. Everyone should play a bit of single player first to get used to playing the game before their screen gets shrunk down to one-quarter of the screen. And to get some money for restocking healing items.

>>9473758
Snippet:
>Interviewer: Obviously, Diablo was a big influence on PSO. How much of Diablo did you play yourself?
>I played quite a lot. Nobody on our team had worked on an online game, so one of the challenges was getting the team to understand what made online games fun. I had a lot of people play the game, but a lot of them were turned off by the dark fantasy. They would say, “it’s disturbing,” or, “I don’t get why it’s fun.” Trying to unify the team and getting them to understand the direction we wanted to take the game in was very difficult.

>Interviewer: Did you have LAN parties, where you played in a controlled environment so that the team could understand the cooperative elements?
>We installed Diablo on everyone’s PC in the office and had a closed LAN and spent many days playing together so that the team could learn what network gaming was all about.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9473764
>Interviewer: Was there a point where you saw people starting to get the appeal, like the satisfaction of seeing a rare item drop, where you felt the team really get into the game?
>Some people like Setsumasa stayed around until 10 or 11 p.m. at night after people left the office. He would connect Diablo to the network and play until morning, wake up to work, and then play again. Some of us weren’t going home much at the time. Some people would go home just to bathe, sleep a few hours, come back into the office to work, and then play Diablo at the office. It was mostly in the name of research, though. There are a number of games that we used as inspiration. Diablo was obviously one of them. I had heard that Dragon Quest was inspired by remaking Ultima with a Japanese audience in mind. So our concept was, “Let’s make a Diablo game that would appeal to the Japanese audience.”

>Interviewer: With good results. Even though Diablo is a distinctly American game, PSO feels like a very distinctly Japanese game. And yet, it’s not just palatable to Japanese gamers but to everyone.
>I think Diablo is an amazing game, but it’s not a game that appeals to Japanese players. Our suspicion was that Japanese gamers would prefer to cooperate and work together to defeat something more than to compete and fight against other players. That’s why we created PSO to be a cooperative role-playing game. Diablo has cooperative elements but it also has PK and an element of killing other player characters. We eliminated those elements and focused on how we could make a fun, cooperative RPG experience. I think that’s the biggest difference between PSO and Diablo.

Because beneath all the RPG elements, the combat has an almost arcadey feel to it that you'd expect from sega, making it fun to play for the gameplay itself rather than just the long-term rewards of EXP and rare loot. There's a satisfying rythm to the combat.
The game doesn't waste your time making you do chores that don't involve combat. No fishing, mining, etc.
It's definitely repetitive, but that's because you spend most of your time doing the fun part; fighting baddies.
Beam down to planet, go through dungeun killing and looting everything, fight boss, beam up to ship, restock consumables, repeat. It's fun.
Then you have the social aspect on top of all that.

I was pretty stupid when I first played PSO. I loved the aesthetics, the world was super cool, and teaming up with my friends to play together was great. I remember all of us getting set up on PC and when all of us were there, we played through either a space station (tutorial?) or the area shown here >>9471891 and it was a fun time until the leader of our party suggested we play the same dungeon again. I recall we had played the same area for around 2 hours before I asked if we could move on, to which the party leader said we weren't really ready for the next area and that we'd need to go through a few more times. It was the first time I can remember experiencing grinding in a video game.

I remember playing on my own after, and making it easily through the next area, but I didn't have experience with these types of games, nor did I really get the whole dungeon-looting loop since I had mostly played linear games that didn't require grinding before that. I fell off, sadly, but I'll always appreciate the atmosphere this series set up with its cool designs, great music, etc. I gave PSU a shot when that came out, I think in a demo version, and it somehow landed with me more than PSO did at the time, but I think it's just simply because I wasn't as stupid with game genres anymore. >>9483058
I think it's mostly the perception of what makes a "good" translation for many people. Phoenix Wright is loved and it practically was a Working Designs style when it started out because of its attempts to go "no this isn't Japan what are you talking about haha hey Maya sure loves to eat HAMBURGERS am I right". But overall anime and Japanese media has become big and ingrained enough that the Working Designs/4Kids/Saban levels of translating something is more met with derision than "oh boy anime". Even when Nintendo tossed memes into localized scripts of their games, people are more likely to groan and wish they weren't there now.

I think part of it too is that Working Designs translated Magic Knights Rayearth, which has the honor of being the last western Sega Saturn game. If it were anything else, sure, but Rayearth was an established franchise and WD putting on their trademark brand of humor soured a lot to them: even back when the game was new, people felt it was an awkward and out of place translation for the game because the anime was available and already had fans. So you have a game that hits a lot of "oh should I check this out" flags (last console release in the west, based on a beloved series, etc) and get hit with "eh, they made it worse" is sort of an "the Emperor isn't wearing any clothes" moment for them.

Also they put an ammo system into Silhouette Mirage and that personally rankled me because it meant you never wanted to experiment with different weapons due to the cost to use them, then they added grinding for money on top of it. They frequently mistook tedium for difficulty.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9491231
Sega Saturn Magazine: Dynamite Deka is called Die Hard Arcade in the West. Is the content the same?
Makoto Uchida: The versions are almost identical. The difference is that in Die Hard Arcade, the building is called the Nakatomi building, and you can see the Nakatomi symbol here and there. That’s been cut out of the Japanese version.
Sega Saturn Magazine: Are there differences between the characters in both versions?
Makoto Uchida: Yes, quite a lot. For Die Hard Arcade, 20th Century Fox told us to not stray from the story of Die Hard too much. Since the movie didn’t revolve around the president [of the U.S.] , we were told to make the girl appearing in the game into the daughter of the head of Nakatomi. The overall story was to be about terrorists taking over the Nakatomi building. The name of the male character (player one) was accordingly changed to John McClane, and the female player character (player two) also got a name that was different from the Japanese version. Content-wise, the games are almost the same, and even the story isn’t that different on the whole.

>>9488185
>ur controller is broken and ur brain too

Says the moron who still refuses to actually play it. Let's read what other people have to say, shall we?

>I prefer the PS1 version in my opinion. It has better controls, the PS1 graphics look great, it has an awesome soundtrack, and I heard it's superior version of the game. It's a really fun Toy Story game it's actually my first PS1 game.

>I have now started playing it on Dreamcast and I am a bit shocked by the analog controls. Basically, the controls work like dpad controls and the analog stick is mapped to the eight directions of a d-pad. This is not too unusual for games originating on PS1 back then, but what is unusual, and also insane, is the fact that the mapping seems to work like this: pick a very small epsilon and then determine for each of the four base directions, if they are pressed like this: if stickdirectionX > epsilon then right = true; if stickdirectionY > epsilon then forward = true (and similar for the opposite directions). As a consequence, if you only slightly deviate from the four base directions, you end up with a diagonal direction. This makes the game near unplayable with the analogstick and everytime I need even a bit of precision, I need to resort to the dpad.

Stop talking out your ass and actually fucking play the game. The Dreamcast version controls like absolute dogshit with the analog stick. Why are you defending a game you haven't even played?

Personally I fucking HATE Smash and I think Smash just plays very very differently from Power Stone. I mean just look at it. Seriously I wish I could get into Smash but it just controls so faggy and while I love Power Stone I have to force myself to play Smash and it is just not enjoyable to me.

Power Stone lives from people sitting next to each other and kicking their ass. The PSP was pretty much the worse system to port it to or does anyone know anything about the sales or if anyone cared for it to be on the PSP? How did it even play on the PSP?

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9487456
the game isn't uninspired. it's pretty fun and quirky. it's definitely not a system seller or mario killer, but it's a pretty solid platformer. i'm not trying to say it's an amazing game everyone should play, but i do believe the game is pretty fun if you do approach it with the right expectations. the game has a lot of old school game design chinese trickery where you sort of have to put yourself in the mind of the developer and try to figure out what traps and pitfalls is set out for you, instead of rushing forward guns blazing. it is that sort of game that dangles an item box down a corridor in a suspicious maner, and you just know some trap is gonna befal you if you go there. i do like that sort of game, provided it isn't too cryptic to figure out or unfair, it's pretty balanced in its approach, you just need to pay attention and just keep in your mind a chinese man programming the game with an evil grim trying to figure out ways to trick you. eventually you figure out the game is all about buying the right items and use them at the right time, instead of trying to do everything with your vanilla moveset, that way you will burn out all your lives unless you're the gamemaster. janken is just a weird quirk of the game, they were experimenting with something goofy, turns out it's not a good idea. either way it's not a big deal, the janken isn't actually random, they do all the same moves provided you don't die, so just take a note of what the right moves are in order and do them next time you play. even though is obviously an RNG dumb mechanic it still plays well with the childish demeaner of the game. in 3 or 4 playthroughs you can beat the game, it isn't hard.

>>9486597
Rather than comparing it to other Zelda games, you should compare it to other games on the system.
The Game Boy was perceived as a system for casual gamers who just wanted to play simple little time wasters like Tetris and not much else, but games like Link's Awakening went on to prove that it's capable of hosting some powerhouse games that are lengthy, adventurous, and can easily stand up to the big boys on console.
The game predates the first Pokémon games by three years, and yet look how much more polished it is. The game is a technical marvel, and as a bonus, for a Zelda game, it probably tells the most coherent and emotional narrative in the series up to that point. The game deserves all the praise it gets and more.

And of course NOAC clones are $20 shipped on Amazon and work pretty damn well for the price.

>>9485826
My girlfriend and I both got Covid back in November of 2020 and we were both quarantined from work for a solid four weeks. Paid, thankfully, but horribly sick for the first week and a half. I got better quicker and I occupied our time by playing Ty the Tasmanian Tiger. Now whenever snow hits our area she wants me to play it again. Plan on starting it in a few days. Other games we usually play around this time of year are Ms. Pacman Maze Madness and Spyro Enter the Dragonfly. I personally have an attachment to that game because as a kid I was really poor, and my original Spyro games had been lost and I couldn't afford to get new copies, so one of the last Christmases I had with my gram before she died, she got me a secondhand Gamecube and a few games, EtD being one of them. She knew how much I loved Spyro when I was younger, and I was happy to have any title at all again, so I played the whole game over the next few visits while she watched. Sorry for blogposting. Happy Holidays anons.

>>9476704
>last bronx imho

Most of the best 3D fighters on the Saturn came from Sega.

- Virtua Fighter (Launch game/ pack-in game)
- Virtua Fighter Remix (given away as free at times)
- Virtua Fighter 2 (arguably one of the best 3D fighters on the console)
- Virtua Fighter Kids (it's Virtua Fighter 2 with big headed 'kid' characters. The gameplay is different from of the different strike ranges.
- Fighting Vipers - It's a defensive styled game that revolves around body armor. The areas are walled too. You can intentionally break off your armour to move faster.
- Fighters MegaMix - Virtua Fighter 2 characters with partial VF3 moves list, vs Fighting Vipers. With other AM2 guest characters.
- Last Bronx - weapon based fighting game, it also has an anime vibe to it.
- Virtual On : This is a bit more like an arena combat game.

Non Sega 3D Fighters:
- Dead or Alive - Japanese only release
- Final Fight Revenge - This one is also a Japan only release and requires the 4MB RAM cart.
- Battle Arena Toshinden -port of the PS1 game
- Battle Arena Toshinden URA - better than the first one
- D-Xhird - weapon based fighter with enclosed arenas
- Criticom
- Rise 2: Resurrection - sequel to Rise of the Robots. It sucks.
- FIST (Japanese only 3D fighter)


The Saturn's third party line up of 3D fighters is a bit hit or miss. But the first party 3D fighters were generally all good IMO. The Saturn has a much bigger selection of third party 2D fighters. Overall, the Saturn was great for fighting games.

>>9485062
>It couldn't do progressive 480p scan (the reason why DoA2 looks better on Dreamcast) but then it suddenly could with Tekken 5 and Gran Turismo 4.

It could do 480p, but then you were left with almost no VRAM left. Most programmers at the time expected VRAM to hold both textures and framebuffer, so they went for small framebuffer and crap textures with 4 colors.

Then years later they figured out they can write a code on the coprocessor that textured from system memory (where they had a massive lead), because the vram was so stupid fast that this was actually practical. After that you had 480p games.
